questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient complains of intermittent epigastric pain that is worse with food intake over the past 3 months. On further evaluation, he was found to have peptic ulcer disease caused by H. pylori. Which of the following drugs is not used in H. pylori eradication?
questions.solution:
Mosapride is a gastrokinetic 5-HT4 agonist and is not indicated in H. pylori eradication.

Proton pump inhibitors like omeprazole or H2 receptor antagonists like cimetidine are usually present in anti-H. pylori regimens for reducing the pH of gastric secretions.

Antimicrobials are used in the treatment of H. pylori infections as well. These include

  • Clarithromycin
  • Metronidazole 
  • Tetracycline
  • Amoxicillin 

H.pylori is a gram-negative motile rod with flagella. It has a unique feature of urease production, which is helpful in diagnosis. The sole source of H.pylori is human gastric mucus. In some patients, H.pylori causes mild acute gastritis lasting for about two weeks. In others, it can cause peptic ulcer disease, which may lead to chronic atrophic gastritis in later stages. This is a risk factor for gastric malignancies like adenocarcinoma and mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphomas. 

Many regimens generally indicated for eradication of H. pylori infections are given below.

questions.text: A young male patient who returned from Africa 12 months ago presents with complaints of excessive itching and rashes present all over his body. The life cycle of the parasite he was infected with is shown in the image. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts the life cycle of Onchocerca volvulus, which is transmitted by the vector, black fly. Ivermectin is the drug of choice for onchocerciasis caused by Oncocerca volvulus in adults and children aged more than 5 years. 

Onchocerciasis may present with subcutaneous nodules or onchocercoma. It is a firm non-tender nodule arising from bony sites like the coccyx and sacrum. It is commonly associated with pruritus and rashes. Patients may also have loose skin with hypo or hyperpigmentation and a leopard skin appearance.

Ivermectin is also a drug of choice for human strongyloidiasis. It is used for chemoprophylaxis of lymphatic filariasis caused by W. bancrofti and B. malayi. It is as effective as diethylcarbamazine in treating lymphatic filariasis. It can also be used in strongyloidiasis, ascariasis and enterobiasis.

Ivermectin activates glutamate-gated Cl channels and GABA-gated channels, which causes muscular paralysis in nematodes. Cestodes and trematodes are not sensitive to ivermectin as they lack receptors for binding.

It is associated with Mazzotti reaction (fever, pruritic rash, lymphadenopathy) as a side effect when given for filariasis due to immune system activation by the deadly parasite. This reaction is also seen with the use of diethylcarbamazine.

  • Chemoprophylaxis of filariasis
  • Strongyloidiasis
  • Gnathostomiasis
  • Scabies

questions.text: A young woman presents with painless warty lesions on the vulva as shown in the image below. Which of the following is a topical agent that can be prescribed for her condition?
questions.solution:
Warty lesions on the vulva as seen in the given image is suggestive of condyloma acuminata caused by HPV (6, 11). Imiquimod is a topical agent with antiviral and immunomodulatory properties indicated in the treatment of external genital and perianal warts.

Other topical agents that can be used include podophyllotoxin and trichloroacetic acid.

questions.text: You are an intern and you see a 67-year-old male patient with a history of liver cirrhosis present to the emergency department with massive hematemesis. He is hemodynamically stable now after the first-line management. Which of the following agents are useful in the medical treatment of variceal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Octreotide is a useful agent in treating variceal bleeding.

Octreotide is a somatostatin analog and controls variceal bleeding by

  • Reducing hepatic and azygous blood flow
  • Reducing hepatic venous wedge pressure
  • Constricting splanchnic arterioles: direct action on vascular smooth muscle.
  • Decreasing hyperdynamic circulatory syndrome of portal hypertension by inhibiting the release of contributing peptides.

Initial management of variceal bleeding involves the following: 

  • Admission to the intensive care unit
  • Placement of two large-bore peripheral cannulae
  • Blood transfusion
  • Correction of coagulopathy with Vitamin K and tranexamic acid
  • Octreotide, a somatostatin analog or terlipressin, a splanchnic vasoconstrictor
  • Prophylactic antibiotic
  • Endotracheal intubation for airway protection if bleeding is uncontrolled
  • Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy

Ultimately, liver transplantation is the only way to definitively treat portal hypertension and variceal bleeding.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presented to the clinic with difficulty in vision. She is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis for which she has been on medication for many years along with drugs for the management of her diabetes and hypertension. Fundus examination of the patient shows the following finding. Which of the following drug could have caused this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts the bull’s eye maculopathy which can be caused by hydroxychloroquine. This patient's history of being treated for rheumatoid arthritis is the most probable reason for the lesion.

Bull's-eye maculopathy refers to the ophthalmoscopic appearance of a central area of retinal pigment epithelial depigmentation surrounded by relatively normal retinal pigment epithelium, giving a "bulls-eye" appearance to the macula.

Hydroxychloroquine, which is generally used for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, toxicity causes bull’s eye maculopathy. Chloroquine binds to melanin in the retinal pigment epithelium, causing cytotoxic effects.

Causes of bull’s eye maculopathy include:

  • Chloroquine
  • Hydroxychloroquine
  • Congenital cone dystrophy

Other adverse effects of chloroquine:

  • Nail bed and mucosal membrane discoloration
  • Irreversible retinopathy
  • Ototoxicity
  • Toxic myopathy
  • Cardiopathy
  • Peripheral neuropathy

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient has been prescribed a drug that catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin for the treatment of his chronic gout. What is this drug?
questions.solution:
The drug that catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin for the treatment of chronic gout is pegloticase.

Pegloticase is a pegylated uricase (urate oxidase) that catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin, which is a more soluble and inactive metabolite. It is used in the treatment of severe, refractory chronic gout or in cases where other urate-lowering therapies are contraindicated. The efficacy of this drug gets lowered if antibodies are produced against the drug, which occurs in many patients. This also increases the risk of infusion reactions. 

Rasburicase is a recombinant uricase. It is indicated for the initial management of elevated plasma uric acid levels in patients with malignancies who are on chemotherapy. The efficacy is limited by the production of antibodies to the drug.

Gout occurs due to the precipitation of urate crystals in the tissues with a subsequent inflammatory response. In an acute episode of gout, there is painful distal monoarthritis which can lead to joint destruction, subcutaneous tophi, and renal calculi. Management of gout includes:

  • Reduction of pain and inflammation: NSAIDs, colchicine, glucocorticoids
  • Inhibition of the formation of urate: Allopurinol, febuxostat
  • Promotion of urate excretion: Probenecid, lesinurad

Other options: 

Option A: Colchicine acts by preventing the polymerization of microtubules by tubulin, this reduces neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissue and also decreases the secretion of chemotactic factors by activated neutrophils. Overall reducing the inflammatory response.

Option B: Febuxostat is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor approved for the treatment of hyperuricemia in patients with gout.

Option D: Allopurinol by inhibiting the xanthine oxidase enzyme prevents the conversion of xanthine to uric acid.

questions.text: A patient has profuse rhinorrhea and sneezing. He was prescribed fexofenadine. Which of the following is false regarding this drug?

choices.text: It is an active metabolite of terfenadine
It is a second-generation H1 receptor antagonists

questions.solution:
Fexofenadine is the active metabolite of terfenadine and it lacks serious side effects like torsade de Pointes of its parent molecule. 

Torsade de pointes occurs due to the inhibition of delayed rectifier K+ channels in the heart at elevated concentrations. Fexofenadine has a low propensity of blocking delayed rectifier K+ channels and does not lead to prolongation of the QTc interval.

H1 antagonists are divided into first-generation and second-generation drugs.

First-generation antihistamines are lipophilic and cross the blood-brain barrier easily and should not be prescribed to drivers and heavy machine workers and pilots because they can cause sedation. They include:

  • Carbinoxamine
  • Diphenhydramine
  • Dimenhydrinate
  • Promethazine
  • Hydroxyzine
  • Chlorpheniramine
  • Cyproheptadine

Second-generation antihistamines are less sedative because of less central nervous system penetration and do not block autonomic receptors. They include:

  • Fexofenadine
  • Loratadine
  • Desloratadine
  • Cetirizine, Levocetirizine

Important uses of H1 receptor blockers:

  • Allergic rhinitis and urticaria- They block histamine-mediated actions
  • Antinausea and antiemetics- scopolamine and dimenhydrinate are used in the treatment of motion sickness. Doxylamine is used in the treatment of vomiting in pregnancy.
  • Antiparkinsonism- Diphenhydramine can be used to suppress extrapyramidal symptoms caused due to antipsychotic medications

Adverse effects

  • Sedation
  • Antimuscarinic action- dry mouth and respiratory passages, urinary retention or frequency

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl was brought with signs and symptoms suggestive of a bleeding disorder. Laboratory tests revealed normal platelet count,  prolonged bleeding time, and defects in platelet aggregation. The Ristocetin aggregation test was normal. Further studies revealed defects in GP IIb/IIIa receptors. Which of the following drugs act on the same receptor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical complex describes a case of Glanzmann's thrombasthenia caused due to deficiency of the glycoprotein IIb-IIIa receptor. Abciximab is an anti-platelet drug that functions by blocking this receptor. 

Other drugs that act by blocking Gp IIb/IIIa receptors are tirofiban and eptifibatide. 

They are mainly used during percutaneous coronary intervention for acute coronary syndrome. They carry a high risk of bleeding and can cause thrombocytopenia.

Note:

Deficiency of the same receptor, Glycoprotein IIb-IIIa, leads to a condition called immune thrombocytopenic purpura. In immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), antibodies are formed in the spleen against the cell-surface antigens GpIIb/IIIa or GpIb/IX, causing increased peripheral destruction of platelets.

Other options:

Option B: Clopidogrel  is an irreversible inhibitor of the ADP (P2Y12) receptor of platelets.

Option C: Low-molecular-weight heparin is an anticoagulant that acts by inhibiting factors Xa and IIa.

Option D: Rivaroxaban is a direct oral factor Xa inhibitor that inhibits the free and clot-associated factor Xa resulting in reduced thrombin generation.

questions.text: Which among the following is a highly emetogenic anticancer drug?
questions.solution:
Cisplatin is a highly emetogenic anticancer drug. Cisplatin causes marked nausea and vomiting in almost all cases and is usually administered along with anti-emetic regimens.

This can usually be controlled with 5HT3 receptor antagonists, neurokinin (NK1) receptor antagonists (e.g., aprepitant), and high-dose corticosteroids.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was diagnosed with constipation and was started on senna laxatives. After 5 months, the patient came to the hospital with complaints of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramping. The colonoscopy of the patient is shown. The diagnosis of this patient is ____________
questions.solution:
The above colonoscopy image depicts a black pigmentation of colonic mucosa that is indicative of melanosis coli. Chronic use of anthraquinone laxatives like senna and cascara sagrada can cause melanosis coil.

As the laxative travels down the intestinal tract, it remains in its inactive form until it reaches the large intestine. Once in the large intestine, the molecules transform into their active form. These active forms of laxative lead to cell damage in the lining of the intestine and death by apoptosis and create a dark pigment, lipofuscin, which eventually lines the large bowel. Eventually, these dead cells are taken up by macrophages. Melanosis coli can occur within only a few months of chronic laxative use. 

Classification of Laxatives

  • Bulk-forming 
    • Dietary fiber: Bran, psyllium/ispaghula, methylcellulose, calcium polycarbophil
  • Stool softener: Docusates (DOSS), Liquid paraffin
  • Stimulant purgatives
    • Diphenylmethanes: bisacodyl, sodium picosulphate
    • Anthraquinones: senna, cascara sagrada
    • 5-HT4 agonist: prucalopride
    • Fixed oil: castor oil
    • Prostaglandin analogue- lubiprostone
  • Osmotic purgatives
    • Magnesium salts: sulfate, hydroxide
    • Sodium salts: sulfate, phosphate
    • Sodium potassium tartrate
    • Lactulose

The main indication of laxatives is the prevention and treatment of acute and chronic constipation.

Docusates are associated with side effects like cramps, abdominal pain, and hepatotoxicity on prolonged usage. Liquid paraffin may be associated with foreign body granulomas, lipid pneumonia, and vitamin deficiencies. Bisacodyl may cause allergic reactions.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child diagnosed with bronchial asthma requires bronchodilator therapy. Which of the following device will you prescribe for this child, to avoid oropharyngeal adverse effects?
questions.solution:
The device in image 3 is a spacer device that can be prescribed to decrease the incidence of propellant-mediated oropharyngeal adverse effects.

Spacers reduce the velocity and size of particles entering the upper airways. This reduces the amount of drug depositing in the oropharynx and increases the proportion of drugs inhaled into the lower airways. Thus, a less amount of the drug gets swallowed and absorbed from the GI tract and limits local side effects. 

Spacer devices are useful in delivering inhaled drugs to children who are not able to use a pMDI alone but can also be used by adults for better drug delivery. The image below shows the use of a spacer device with a face mask which is preferred in children younger than 3 years of age.


The various devices used for the delivery of inhalational drugs are:

Pressurized metered-dose inhalers (pMDI) - Drugs are propelled from a canister in the pMDI with the aid of a propellant. These devices are convenient, portable, and can deliver 50–200 doses of a drug.

Image 1 in the question stem shows a pressurized metered-dose inhaler.


Dry powder inhalers - these devices scatter the drug into a fine powder that is dispersed by air turbulence on inhalation. DPIs have been developed to deliver drugs such as insulin, but the dosing is inconsistent. Children below 7 years find it difficult to use a DPI. 

Image 2 in the question stem shows a dry powder inhaler.


Nebulizers: Two types of nebulizer are available -

  • Jet nebulizers that are driven by a stream of gas (air or oxygen)
  • Ultrasonic nebulizers that use a rapidly vibrating piezoelectric crystal and thus do not require a source of compressed gas.

The nebulizers deliver much higher drug doses as compared pMDIs. These are useful in:

  • Treating acute exacerbations of asthma and COPD
  • Extreme airway obstruction (severe COPD)
  • Delivering inhaled drugs to infants and small children who cannot use the other inhalation devices
  • Administering drugs such as antibiotics in relatively high doses

Image 4 in the question stem shows a nebulizer.

questions.solution:
Option B is correctly matched.

Drug  Antidote
1. Heparin b. Protamine sulfate
2. Dabigatran c. Idarucizumab
3. Warfarin a. Vitamin K
4. Rivaroxaban d. Andexanet alfa


Heparin - Protamine sulfate(1-b) :

Protamine sulfate is indicated for the reversal of heparin overdose. It binds to long heparin molecules with high affinity and neutralizes anticoagulant activity. Therefore, it completely reverses the action of unfractionated heparin but only partially reverses the action of low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH). It has no effect on fondaparinux.

Dabigatran - Idarucizumab (2-c) :

Idarucizumab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically acts as a reversal agent for dabigatran. It has a 350 times higher affinity for dabigatran than dabigatran for thrombin. Hence, it forms a complex with dabigatran, which is excreted by the kidneys.

Warfarin - Vitamin K (3-a) :

Vitamin K is given orally as well as intravenously to treat warfarin toxicity. It causes the reversal of anticoagulation effects of warfarin by synthesis of vitamin K–dependent coagulation factors (II, VII, IX, X).

Rivaroxaban - Andexanet alfa (4-d) :

Andexanet alfa is a recombinant analog of factor Xa and is used as a reversal agent for oral factor Xa inhibitors like rivaroxaban, edoxaban, and apixaban. It rapidly reverses the action of these drugs and restores thrombin generation. It is given intravenously.

Note:

Ciraparantag is considered a potential reversal agent against all direct anticoagulants, including dabigatran, rivaroxaban, apixaban, and edoxaban, as well as heparin and LMWH. This drug is in the early stages of development.

questions.text: A pregnant female at 36 weeks gestation, presents with palpitations, protrusion of the eyeball, and heat intolerance. On blood investigations, it was found that she had increased T3 and T4 levels and decreased TSH levels.  Which of the following should be the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is thyrotoxicosis. As she is in her third trimester, the drug of choice for the treatment of thyrotoxicosis is methimazole.

Treatment of thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy has been summarized in the table below.

Trimester Treatment options
First trimester

Propylthiouracil
Second trimester Methimazole (preferred)
Subtotal thyroidectomy
Third trimester Methimazole

Thyrotoxicosis during pregnancy is usually controlled by thioamide drugs. Propylthiouracil was preferred previously because it partially inhibits the conversion of T4 to T3 and crosses the placenta less readily than methimazole. However, since it has a higher risk of causing propylthiouracil-associated liver failure in pregnancy, methimazole is prescribed according to guidelines in the second trimester and third trimesters. Methimazole is usually avoided in the first trimester due to methimazole-associated embryopathy. 

Other options:

Option B: Subtotal thyroidectomy is done once the hyperthyroidism is medically controlled. It is usually avoided during pregnancy, however, may be done in some cases in the second trimester where it can't be controlled via medication.

Option D: Radioactive iodine is contraindicated in pregnant women as it may cause fetal thyroid gland destruction.

A young male patient presents to the clinic with the following condition. After taking a detailed past medical and drug history of this patient, your senior asks you about the drugs implicated in this condition. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be your answer?
  1. Digoxin
  2. Risperidone
  3. Ketoconazole
  4. Spironolactone
  5. α-methyl-dopa
  6. Eplerenone
questions.solution:
The image above depicts gynecomastia in a young male patient and drugs causing gynecomastia include 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5.

Gynecomastia occurs as a result of an imbalance between estrogens, which stimulate breast tissue, and androgens, which counteract these effects. 

The most common causes are as follows: 

  • Physiological gynecomastia
  • Cirrhosis of the liver
  • Thyrotoxicosis
  • Alcohol
  • Antiretroviral therapy
  • Anabolic steroids
  • Klinefelter syndrome (XXY karyotype)
  • Functioning testicular neoplasms, such as the Leydig cell or Sertoli cell tumors.
  • Drugs - Digoxin, risperidone, ketoconazole, spironolactone, α-methyldopa, cimetidine, phenytoin therapy. Eplerenone is selective for the mineralocorticoid receptor and therefore does not cause gynecomastia.

Physiologic gynecomastia occurs during three phases of life:

  • Neonatal period
  • Adolescence
  • Senescence

Common to each of these phases is an excess of circulating estrogens in relation to circulating testosterone. In neonates, it is caused by the action of placental estrogens on neonatal breast tissues. In adolescence, there is an excess of estradiol relative to testosterone. In senescence, the circulating testosterone level falls, resulting in relative hyperestrogenism.

questions.text: A morbidly obese, diabetic woman did not respond well to metformin therapy. She has a history of pancreatitis and a family history of bladder cancer. The patient does not want to take injections. Which of the following would be suitable to reduce her glucose levels?
questions.solution:
The most suitable drug to reduce this patient's blood glucose level is canagliflozin.

Canagliflozin is a sodium-glucose transporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor. Other SGLT-2 inhibitors include dapagliflozin and empagliflozin. They act by inhibiting the SGLT-2 transporter which is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule and responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose. It inhibits glucose reabsorption resulting in glycosuria and a change in the renal threshold. This results in a decrease in blood glucose levels. 

The common side effects include urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the high glucose content of the urine. There is a risk of the development of euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis. It increases the risk of fractures and lower limb amputations due to the creation of an imbalance with the minerals and circulating parathormone and vitamin D. 

Other options:

Option A: Liraglutide (GLP-1 agonist) cannot be used as it is can be given only parenterally and the patient insists on taking medications via the non-parenteral route.

Option B: Sitagliptin cannot be given since the drug increases the risk of fatal and non-fatal pancreatitis. The patient is already suffering from pancreatitis.

Option D: Pioglitazone is associated with bladder cancer. The patient has a family history of bladder cancer.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presented with a complaint of lower backache. The MRI of her lumbosacral spine is given below. Her bone mineral density is measured, and her T-score is -2.8. She is given oral drugs, but she develops esophagitis. Which of the following intravenous treatment plans would be useful in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray depicts the ballooning of disc spaces, leading to the biconcave shape of the vertebral body, which is known as the ‘codfish' appearance. Along with a T-score of -2.8, it is diagnostic of postmenopausal osteoporosis. Zoledronate 5 mg intravenous annually is used in the management of postmenopausal osteoporosis. It belongs to a class of drugs called bisphosphonates.

Bisphosphonates inhibit bone resorption and thus are very effective for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis. They get concentrated at sites of active remodeling and remain in the matrix until the bone is remodeled. Then, they are released in the acid environment of the resorption lacunae and induce apoptosis in osteoclasts.

Routes of administration - Certain bisphosphonates like etidronate, alendronate, risedronate, and tiludronate may be administered orally, while others like zoledronate, ibandronate, and pamidronate can be given intravenously. Intravenous formulations are given when oral formulations cannot be taken due to side effects like esophagitis.

Zoledronate: It can be administered via intravenous infusion for over 15 minutes. It is given once a year, and the dose given is 5 mg for osteoporosis in postmenopausal females. A single 5-mg infusion of zoledronate is also used for the treatment of Paget disease, lowering bone turnover markers for 6 months without losing its therapeutic impact. For patients with hormone-treated prostate and breast cancer, zoledronate is frequently given to prevent osteoporosis. Both vertebral and nonvertebral fractures are decreased by it. For the treatment of multiple myeloma, bone metastases from solid tumors, or hypercalcemia of malignancy, a 4-mg formulation is offered for intravenous administration. 

Other options:

Options A and B - Teriparatide is a recombinant parathormone analog that has an anabolic effect on bone homeostasis when given intermittently. It acts by increasing osteoblastic activity. It increases bone mineral density and decreases the risk of fractures in postmenopausal women. It is administered as a subcutaneous injection of 20 μg once daily.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 33 weeks of gestation presents to your antenatal clinic with preterm labour.  Which corticosteroid will you administer for stimulation of fetal lung maturation?
questions.solution:
Betamethasone is indicated for the stimulation of fetal lung maturation in preterm labor.

As compared to cortisol, betamethasone binds to maternal proteins less and has less placental metabolism. This allows increased transfer to the fetus. Additionally, infants exposed to betamethasone are less likely to require postnatal resuscitation. 2 doses of 12 mg each are administered 18-24 hours apart when the delivery is anticipated before 34 weeks of gestation.

Dexamethasone is another long-acting glucocorticoid that can be given. It has benefits such as less risk of intraventricular hemorrhage and a shorter length of stay in the NICU.

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady with grade 2 osteoarthritis is on treatment with NSAIDs. She developed heartburn and epigastric pain. An upper GI endoscopy revealed gastritis. Which of the following is the most appropriate advice for her pharmacologically?

choices.text: Stop NSAIDs and chew capsule pantoprazole for rapid action
Switch to etoricoxib instead of NSAIDs and use pantoprazole capsule without chewing
Use a combination of antacid and cimetidine for rapid healing
Switch to ranitidine along with sucralfate

questions.solution:
Among the given options, switching to etoricoxib instead of a non-selective COX inhibitor and using pantoprazole without chewing would be the most appropriate advice.

Selective COX2 inhibitors like etoricoxib are less likely to cause gastritis than non-selective COX inhibitors like aspirin or ibuprofen.

Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) like pantoprazole are generally coated or available in capsule forms. Without this, it gets degraded by the action of gastric acid. Hence uncrushed PPI should be used 1/2 to 1 hour before the meals.

Other options:

Option A: NSAIDs may be stopped in view of gastric irritation and switched to another analgesic or surgical option might be undertaken. PPI should not be crushed.

Option C: A combination of H2 blockers like cimetidine and antacid should not be administered simultaneously, as the antacids reduce the absorption of all H2 blockers. At least a gap of 2 hours should be maintained.

Option D: Ranitidine increases the gastric pH (i.e. less acidic) which reduces sucralfate efficacy; hence the combination is incorrect. 

Note: Usage of ranitidine for any purpose has been banned by the FDA due to a potential carcinogenic agent in a few batches of this drug.

questions.text:
Which of the following are mechanisms of action of dapsone?
  1. Inhibits dihydropteroate synthase
  2. Inhibits neutrophil myeloperoxidase
  3. Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR)
  4. Inhibits neutrophil migration
  5. Inhibits thymidylate synthase
questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of dapsone includes:

  1. Inhibition of dihydropteroate synthase
  2. Inhibition of neutrophil myeloperoxidase
  3. Inhibition of neutrophil migration

Dapsone is a structural analogue of PABA and competitively inhibits dihydropteroate synthase in the folate pathway.

The anti-inflammatory effects of dapsone occur due to the inhibition of:

  1. Tissue damage by neutrophils
  2. Neutrophil myeloperoxidase activity and respiratory burst
  3. Migration of neutrophils to inflammatory lesions

Dapsone may also act as a neutrophil-free-radical scavenger.

Dapsone is used in the treatment of leprosy, malaria, P. jiroveci infection, and toxoplasma prophylaxis. Its anti-inflammatory property is the basis for the treatment of pemphigoid, dermatitis herpetiformis, linear IgA bullous disease, etc.

Adverse effects include hemolysis at doses of 200-300mg and methemoglobinemia.

Note: Dapsone does not cause inhibition of DHFR or thymidylate synthase. Methotrexate and pemetrexed are dihydrofolate reductase inhibitors. 5-Fluorouracil (5FU) and capecitabine are thymidylate synthase inhibitors.

questions.text:
In which of the following conditions can rifampicin be used?
  1. Prophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis
  2. Treatment of brucellosis
  3. Eradication of staphylococcal nasal carrier state
  4. Treatment of pleuropulmonary nocardiosis
  5. Treatment of paucibacillary leprosy
questions.solution:
Besides its anti-tubercular action, rifampicin also has certain non-tubercular uses which include:

  • Prophylaxis of meningococcal and H. influenzae meningitis
  • Treatment of MRSA, diphtheroid, and legionella infections 
  • Eradication of staphylococcal nasal carrier state in patients with chronic furunculosis
  • A combination of doxycycline and rifampicin is used as the first-line therapy for brucellosis
  • A part of the WHO regimen for standard therapy of both paucibacillary and multibacillary leprosy

Rifampicin is not used in the treatment of Nocardia species. Cotrimoxazole is considered the drug of choice for pleuropulmonary nocardiosis.

questions.text: Arrange the following formulations of amphotericin B (AMB) according to the increasing order of nephrotoxicity.

choices.text: Conventional-AMB < Amphotericin B lipid complex < Liposomal amphotericin B
Liposomal amphotericin B < Conventional-AMB < Amphotericin B lipid complex
Conventional-AMB < Liposomal amphotericin B < Amphotericin B lipid complex
Liposomal amphotericin B < Amphotericin B lipid complex < Conventional-AMB

questions.solution:
The correct order of nephrotoxicity with amphotericin B formulations is liposomal amphotericin B < amphotericin B lipid complex < conventional-amphotericin B.

Nephrotoxicity with amphotericin B:

All lipid formulations of amphotericin B are less nephrotoxic than conventional amphotericin B. Liposomal amphotericin B is less nephrotoxic than amphotericin B lipid complex, especially in patients with a higher risk of nephrotoxicity. Azotemia is seen in 80% of cases with C-AMB. Renal tubular acidosis and renal wasting of potassium and magnesium are seen. Nephrotoxicity can be reduced by saline loading. 

Other adverse effects:

Infusion-related reactions - It is most prominent with amphotericin B colloidal dispersion. Fever and chills following IV injection is a major acute reactions. Tachypnea, hypotension, or respiratory stridor may be also seen. Meperidine is used to shorten the reaction.

Hypochromic normocytic anemia may be seen due to decreased erythropoietin.

Headache, nausea, malaise, vomiting, and phlebitis at the site of injection is also seen.

Arachnoiditis may be seen with intrathecal injections.

Formulations of amphotericin B:

C-AMB(Conventional amphotericin B): It is formulated with bile salt deoxycholate and is given as an intravenous infusion.

ABCD(Amphotericin B colloidal dispersion): It is formed by equimolar concentrations of amphotericin B and cholesteryl sulfate.

L-AMB(Liposomal amphotericin B): Here amphotericin B is incorporated within a small liposomal vesicle.

ABLC(Amphotericin B lipid complex): It is a complex of amphotericin B with two phospholipids.

Related Pearl: Nephrotoxicity risk with Amphotericin-B formulations (decreasing order)

Nephrotoxicity Risk with Amphotericin B formulations:
  • Conventional amphotericin B (C-AMB) has the highest risk of nephrotoxicity.
  • C-AMB > Amphotericin B lipid complex > Liposomal amphotericin B.
Amphotericin B colloidal dispersion has not been compared with other lipid-based formulations.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, in the first trimester of pregnancy from a tribal area, presented with fever and chills for the last 3 days. After examination of the peripheral smear given below, chloroquine was started but there was no improvement in the patient's condition. Which of the following is preferred for treating this patient?
questions.solution:
Quinine plus clindamycin is preferred for the treatment of chloroquine-resistant falciparum malaria in the 1st trimester of pregnancy.

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of a chloroquine-resistant malarial infection. The image given shows ring forms/ early trophozoites in erythrocytes, which are binucleate (double chromatin) and resemble stereo headphones in appearance, characteristic of malaria caused by P. falciparum. 

Worldwide most infections with P. falciparum malaria are resistant to chloroquine. In the 1st trimester, pregnant women diagnosed with uncomplicated malaria caused by chloroquine-resistant P. falciparum infection, the drug of choice is a combination of quinine and clindamycin. Artemisinin-based combination therapy can be used as an alternative for patients that are unable to tolerate oral quinine.

In the second and third trimesters, they can be treated with artemisinin combination therapy such as:

  • Artemether-lumefantrine
  • Artesunate-amodiaquine
  • Artesunate-mefloquine
  • Dihydroartemisinin-piperaquine
  • Artesunate + clindamycin

During pregnancy, P. vivax malaria is treated with chloroquine as it is safe in pregnancy and children. In chloroquine-resistant vivax cases, clindamycin, quinine, chloroquine, and proguanil can be used.

Other options:

Option B: Doxycycline is useful in the treatment of malaria but not used in pregnancy.

Options C: Artemether plus lumefantrine is not the drug of choice in the 1st trimester of pregnancy. ACT may be given in the first trimester only if oral quinine is not tolerated or not available.

Option D: ACT with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine is avoided in the first trimester.

questions.text:
Match the following antiretroviral drugs with their correct groups:
Drug Group
1. Raltegravir A. Protease inhibitor
2. Darunavir B. Entry inhibitor
3. Maraviroc C. Nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor
4. Tenofovir D. Integrase inhibitor
questions.solution:
Option C is correctly matched.

Drug Group
1. Raltegravir D. Integrase inhibitor
2. Darunavir A. Protease inhibitor
3. Maraviroc B. Entry inhibitor
4. Tenofovir C. Nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor

The aim of antiretroviral therapy in HIV is to maximally suppress the viral replication as much as possible for the maximum possible time. For that purpose, current guidelines recommend using at least three drugs from different groups in combination. It is also recommended to change them over time when drug resistance occurs.

Raltegravir is an integrase inhibitor indicated in the treatment of HIV. It acts by inhibiting the catalytic activity of the HIV-encoded integrase and prevents the integration of virus DNA into the host chromosome. 

Darunavir is a protease inhibitor that acts by blocking the viral protease enzyme. It inhibits the replication of both HIV 1 and 2.

Maraviroc is an entry inhibitor. It is a chemokine receptor antagonist that binds to the host cell CCR5 receptor to block the binding of viral gp120. They are also used to manage HIV infection.

Tenofovir is a reverse transcriptase inhibitor that prevents the conversion of viral RNA into proviral DNA. It helps to prevent infection of susceptible cells but does not eradicate the virus from cells that are integrated with proviral DNA. It is active against HIV 1, 2, and HBV.

The current NACO guidelines recommend that all persons diagnosed with HIV infection should be started on antiretroviral treatment regardless of the
CD4 count, WHO clinical stage, age, or population sub-group. The preferred first-line treatment is a fixed drug combination of the TLD regimen consisting of:

  • Tenofovir (TDF 300 mg)
  • Lamivudine (3TC 300 mg) 
  • Dolutegravir (DTG 50 mg) 

Alternate regimens are available in cases where this regimen cannot be used.

questions.text: A patient who was hospitalized and started on an intravenous antibiotic has developed diarrhea. The findings of the colonoscopy are given below. Which of the following antibiotic is most likely to be responsible?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient with hospital-acquired diarrhea (nosocomial) following antibiotic administration is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis most likely due to clindamycin. 

Pseudomembranous colitis is an advanced form of clostridium difficile infection (CDI) that is visualized at endoscopy. Pseudomembranes are seen as whitish yellow plaques on the mucosa. Clostridium difficile infection is the most commonly diagnosed nosocomial diarrhea. It is commonly seen in individuals who receive a prolonged antibiotic course, that causes a change in the composition of gastrointestinal microbial flora. This leads to the colonization of C. difficile.

Antibiotics that may cause CDI are:

  • Clindamycin
  • Ampicillin
  • Cephalosporins- cefotaxime, ceftriaxone, cefuroxime, and ceftazidime
  • Fluroquinolones- ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, and moxifloxacin

Clinical features include diarrhea, lower abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis. The diagnosis is based on clinical criteria: 

  • Diarrhea without other recognized causes, and
  • Detection of toxin A or B in the stool, toxin-producing C. difficile in the stool 

Discontinuation of the offending antimicrobial, if possible, is the first step in management. Oral vancomycin and fidaxomicin (Option B) are used for the treatment of pseudomembranous colitis, depending on its severity. 

Other options:

Option A: Daptomycin may cause allergic pneumonitis in patients receiving prolonged therapy for more than 2 weeks.

Option D: Chloramphenicol is mainly associated with adverse effects such as bone marrow suppression, and hypersensitivity reactions. When given to infants, it may cause grey baby syndrome.

questions.text: An infant on antibiotics becomes very irritable. Investigations reveal increased intracranial pressure. However, the condition resolves on discontinuation of the drug. Which drug had the baby likely been on?
questions.solution:
The given scenario depicts a case of pseudotumor cerebri and tetracyclines are associated with this condition in infants, even when given in normal doses. Only elevated intracranial pressure is seen without any abnormality in the spinal fluid. Increased pressure returns to normal after therapy is discontinued.

Other side effects of tetracyclines are:

  • Teratogenic
  • Deposit in developing teeth and bones, cause brownish discoloration of teeth (chelating property)
  • Marked suppression of normal flora of intestine causing superinfection. Pseudomembranous enterocolitis is a rare side effect

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy visits his doctor to discuss his opioid addiction. 2 years ago he tried to cut down on his opioid consumption but developed excessive sweating, lacrimation, and yawning. He wants to quit now with the help of medications. Which of the following will not be useful in this patient?
questions.solution:
Disulfiram will not be useful for the treatment of opioid detoxification. It is used in cases of chronic alcoholism.

Two years back when the patient tried to cut down his opioid intake, he experienced opioid withdrawal symptoms. Symptoms begin 8-10 hours after the last consumed dose. Initially, symptoms include

  • Lacrimation
  • Rhinorrhea
  • Yawning
  • Sweating 

Later, the patient develops

  • Restless sleep
  • Weakness, chills, gooseflesh (“cold turkey”)
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Muscle aches and involuntary movements (“kicking the habit”)
  • Hyperpnea
  • Hyperthermia
  • Hypertension

The treatment for the opioid withdrawal includes:

Opioid agonists (methadone) or partial agonists (buprenorphine) administered orally or sublingually may be substituted for injectable narcotics. 

Lofexidine and clonidine are alpha 2 agonists which can ameliorate symptoms of opioid withdrawal. Lofexidine is the first non-opioid treatment for managing opioid withdrawal symptoms in adults approved by the FDA in 2018.

Naltrexone, a long-acting opioid antagonist, is used as an adjunct if the patient is already opioid-free. Administration of naltrexone to patients that are opioid-dependent will precipitate acute withdrawal symptoms.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient was diagnosed with parkinsonism. She was commenced on combination therapy with co-careldopa. What is the rationale behind this combination therapy?

choices.text: To decrease the plasma half life of levodopa
To inhibit the metabolism of levodopa in brain
To promote the metabolism of levodopa in periphery
To reduce the systemic side effects of levodopa

questions.solution:
The rationale behind the combination therapy of levodopa with a peripheral DOPA decarboxylase inhibitor like carbidopa (co-careldopa) is that inhibition of the metabolism of levodopa (i.e. conversion of levodopa into dopamine) in the peripheral circulation decreases the systemic side effects of levodopa, like vomiting.

Peripheral dopa decarboxylase inhibitors (carbidopa) do not cross the blood-brain barrier. Therefore, they only inhibit the conversion of levodopa into dopamine in the periphery and not in the brain. This leads to the increased plasma half-life of levodopa, and therefore, lower doses of levodopa can be prescribed.

Benefits of combination therapy:

  • This therapy inhibits the metabolism of levodopa in the periphery, leading to increased plasma half-life of levodopa.
  • Combination therapy reduces adverse effects like gastrointestinal side effects, orthostatic hypotension, and cardiac arrhythmias.
  • This therapy allows for increased availability of levodopa in the brain.
  • Fluctuation in motor control, where the patient is alternately well and disabled, occurs on prolonged therapy with levodopa. This type of "on-off" effect is reduced in combination therapy because of sustained dopamine levels in the brain.
  • Pyridoxine enhances the peripheral metabolism of levodopa. Hence, combination therapy with carbidopa nullifies the interaction of pyridoxine with levodopa metabolism.
  •  A higher degree of improvement is seen in combination therapy than in monotherapy with levodopa.

Demerits of combination therapy:

This therapy decreases the concentration of levodopa in the periphery, but increases the concentration of levodopa reaching the brain. Involuntary movements and behavioral adverse effects like confusion, hallucinations, nightmares, and delusions are not reduced after the addition of carbidopa. In fact, they are increased in patients who are taking levodopa with peripheral carboxylase inhibitors. This is because higher levels of dopamine are formed in CNS.

questions.text: A psychiatric patient with a history of bipolar disorder is brought by her relatives. They give a history suggestive of an acute manic episode. She is already on lithium therapy and the serum lithium levels are measured to be 0.2 mEq/L. What steady-state concentration will you be aiming to achieve in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing increased activity, energy, and euphoria with a decreased need for sleep is indicative of an acute manic episode for which a steady-state concentration of 0.8 - 1.2 mEq/L of lithium has to be achieved for adequate treatment.

Lithium is used in the management of bipolar disorder, and mania, and has anti-suicidal properties. It has a narrow therapeutic index, and blood levels in excess of this may cause symptoms of toxicity. Therapeutic drug monitoring is done by measuring lithium levels 12 hours after the last dose.

Lithium therapy for acute mania:

  • Three individual 10-mg/kg doses of a sustained-release preparation administered at 2-h intervals.
  • The sustained-release form is used to minimize GI adverse effects (e.g., nausea, diarrhea)
  • Subsequent treatment may then be continued with Li+ carbonate.

Steady state-concentrations for therapy :

  • For maintainance therapy in bipolar disorder - 0.5-0.8 mEq/L
  • For episodes of acute mania - 0.8-1.2 mEq/L
  • Toxic levels - >1.5 mEq/L

The blood sample for serum lithium estimation is to be collected after a time interval of 10-12 hours from the previous dose of lithium which is used to estimate the steady-state concentration.

Known significant side effects of lithium therapy include

  • Polyuria-polydipsia (nephrogenic diabetes insipidus)
  • Hand tremors
  • Confusion 
  • ECG changes
  • Psoriasis
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Diarrhea

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient presented with right-sided flank pain which radiates to the groin. She also reports nausea and one episode of vomiting. Her X-Ray abdomen is shown below. She has been on regular medication for a seizure disorder. Which of the following drugs can be implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing acute symptoms of right flank pain radiating to the groin along with bilateral stones in the abdominal x-ray makes renal calculi a likely diagnosis, which is commonly associated with the antiepileptic drug Topiramate.

Acute renal colic presents with sudden onset of severe pain originating in the flank and radiating inferiorly and anteriorly. At least half the patients will also present with nausea and vomiting. Patients with renal calculi may report infection or hematuria.

Topiramate is an anti-epileptic that can be used as initial mono-drug therapy for 

  • Focal seizures
  • GTCS
  • Lennox-Gastaut syndrome in patients ≥ 2 years 

Mechanism of action: Topiramate acts by

  • Reducing voltage-gated Na+ currents 
  • Activating a hyperpolarizing K+ current
  • Enhancing postsynaptic GABAA receptor currents
  • Limiting the activation of glutamate receptors. 

The drug is also a weak inhibitor of renal carbonic anhydrase and can lead to metabolic acidosis. Metabolic acidosis causes hypocitraturia and hypercalciuria that increase urinary saturation and predispose to the formation of renal calculi.

Other options :

Option A: Ezogabine causes urinary retention and blue pigmentation of the skin.

Option C: Vigabatrin causes bilateral vision loss and a contraction of the visual field.

Option D: Oxcarbazepine causes side effects similar to carbamazepine which include hyponatremia and Stevens-Johnson syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of desmopressin that is used in the treatment of central diabetes insipidus?
questions.solution:
Desmopressin is a V2 receptor agonist of vasopressin. It is the drug of choice for central diabetes insipidus.

Diabetes insipidus can be of two types - central or peripheral (nephrogenic). Central DI occurs due to a deficiency of ADH. 

Central diabetes insipidus (DI) is a disorder that occurs due to damage to the neurohypophysis in the posterior pituitary. It can be congenital or acquired. It is characterized by decreased ADH leading to large volumes of urine production. Patients present with excessive thirst, nocturia, and urinary frequency. 

Central DI can be treated with desmopressin, a V2 receptor agonist of vasopressin. It can be given by iv or sc injection, nasal inhalation, or orally. 

Principal cells in the collecting duct have V2 receptors on their basolateral membrane. When stimulated, they increase the insertion rate of water channels - aquaporin2, into the apical membrane. This increases water permeability. V2 receptors also increase the permeability of urea and help in the renal conservation of water.

Activating endothelial V2 receptors by desmopressin or vasopressin increases circulating levels of procoagulant factor VIII and the von Willebrand factor.

questions.text: A patient who was being treated for an arrhythmia presented with palpitations and chest discomfort. His ECG has been given below. Which of the following drugs would be least likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The ECG of this patient shows wide QRS complexes and an undulating baseline suggesting the diagnosis of torsades de pointes. It is associated with prolonged QT interval. Lidocaine does not prolong the QT interval, hence, it is unlikely to cause torsades de pointes. 

Lidocaine belongs to the class IB antiarrhythmic agent. It is considered to have the least arrhythmogenic potential among antiarrhythmic. QT interval is usually unaltered or slightly reduced with lidocaine use.

Among the antiarrhythmics, class Ia and class III drugs prolong action potential duration and thus prolong QT interval and are also prone to cause Torsades de pointes.

Torsade de Pointes is a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. It is characterized by a premature ventricular beat that induces a pause, followed by a sinus beat with a longer QT interval. The T wave is interrupted by a premature ventricular beat, which is the first beat of the polymorphic VT.

Management of a patient with Torsade de Pointes if the tachycardia is stable, includes IV MgSO4, 1-2g over 5-60 minutes, followed by an infusion, which is highly effective for both treatment and prevention, of recurrence of long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that trigger torsades de pointes. Discontinue the offending drug and correct electrolyte abnormalities. 

If this condition progresses into ventricular fibrillation, the appropriate course of action is to perform defibrillation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient presented with the following finding. Her medical history includes hypertension for which she has been taking regular medications for the past 3 months. Which of the following medication is most likely to be associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The image shows pitting pedal edema in a hypertensive patient. Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) like amlodipine are most likely to be associated with peripheral edema.

The frequency of CCB- induced peripheral edema is both drug-specific (i.e more potent drugs like amlodipine will be associated with higher rates of developing edema) and dose-dependent (i.e incidence of edema increases with an increase in drug dosage and chronicity of its usage). It is more common among females.

CCB-induced peripheral edema occurs due to a disproportionate decrease in the arteriolar resistance than in the venous circulation, resulting in increased hydrostatic pressure in the precapillary circulation. This leads to a fluid shift into the interstitial compartment causing edema.

Treatment:

  • Dose reduction.
  • Interclass switching of CCB - switch to non-dihydropyridines like verapamil, and diltiazem.
  • Addition of a venodilator - ACE inhibitor, ARBs, Nitrates.
  • Others - compression stockings, avoiding prolonged upright position.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with peptic ulcer disease is being treated with sucralfate. Which of the following adverse effects can be seen in the patient?
questions.solution:
Gastric bezoar can be seen in a patient taking sucralfate. Sucralfate produces a viscous gel that has a ‘sticky nature’. The sticky nature may be responsible for gastric bezoars, particularly in those with gastroparesis.

Sucralfate is composed of a sulfate of sucrose with Al(OH)3. It undergoes cross-linking to produce a viscous polymer that sticks to epithelial cells and ulcers in acidic environments. It inhibits hydrolysis of the mucosal proteins by pepsin.

It is used in the prophylaxis of stress ulcers, and in conditions where mucosal ulceration is not responding to acid suppression.

Adverse effects of sucralfate include constipation and bezoar formation. It may inhibit absorption of other drugs like digoxin, cimetidine, ketoconazole, and fluoroquinolone antibiotics due to the viscous layer formed in the stomach. Hence it should be taken at least 2 hours after administration if these drugs.

The other options:

Vitamin B12 deficiency and increased risk of bone fractures are side effects of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs). However, their clinical significance has not been proven yet. Hypergastrinemia is more commonly seen with PPIs than H2 receptor antagonists.

questions.text: A patient with Prinzmetal angina is administered isosorbide mononitrate and is noticed to have symptomatic relief. What is the mechanism of action of nitrate in this case?

choices.text: Increased left ventricular end diastolic volume

questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of nitrates in prinzmetal angina is endothelium-independent coronary vasodilatation.

Prinzmetal angina occurs due to vasospasm of the coronary arteries. Nitrates relax the smooth muscles of epicardial coronary arteries and relieve coronary artery spasm.

In the case of stable angina, the primary mechanism of action of nitrates is preferential dilatation of veins (by increasing cGMP). Venous dilatation leads to a decrease in the venous return to the heart (preload). This decreases the ventricular end-diastolic volume and thereby a decrease in myocardial oxygen consumption. The diastolic perfusion pressure (aortic blood pressure in diastole - left ventricular pressure in diastole) is increased.

B. Carvedilol  2. Non-selective, intrinsic agonist

questions.solution:
Pindolol  Non-selective, intrinsic agonist
Carvedilol  Non-selective, antioxidant
Betaxolol  Beta 1 selective, membrane stabilizing

Pindolol is a non-selective first-generation β-blocker with significant intrinsic agonist activity, which may result in a smaller reduction in heart rate and blood pressure. This is useful in patients with diminished cardiac reserve or at risk of bradycardia.

Carvedilol is a non-selective third-generation β-blocker with antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. These properties make it useful in the treatment of congestive heart failure.

Betaxolol is a β1 selective third-generation β-blocker with additional calcium entry blockade activity and a slight membrane-stabilizing property. It does not have agonist activity.

Acebutolol is a β1 selective second-generation β blocker having both membrane-stabilizing and intrinsic agonist activity. It is useful in the treatment of atrial and ventricular arrhythmias.

questions.text: A drug having a half-life of 8 hours is administered orally thrice daily. How much time will be taken for the plasma concentration to reach a steady state?
questions.solution:
The time taken to reach steady-state plasma concentration is 4-5 half-lives. As the half-life of the given drug is 8 hours, so it will take 32-40 hours to reach a steady state. Hence, 36 hours will be the most appropriate answer.

Steady-state: The amount of drug administered is equal to the amount of drug eliminated within one dosing interval resulting in a plateau or constant drug plasma concentration, with the plasma concentration fluctuating between a minimum and maximum.

The time taken to reach steady-state plasma concentration is 4-5 half-lives.

Drugs with a shorter half-life reach a steady state rapidly, whereas drugs with longer half-life take days to weeks to attain a steady state.

Steady-state concentration (Css) = F x Dosing rate/ CL

  • where dosing rate is the dose per time interval and is dose/T
  • F is the fractional bioavailability, CL is clearance.

In the case of intravenous infusion,

Steady-state concentration (Css) = Rate of infusion/ CL

Pharmacokinetics of repeated drug dosing:

Plasma concentration of the drug will increase, reach a maximum, and decline after the first dose. A second dose will be administered before the first dose is completely eliminated. Consequently, the plasma concentration resulting from the second dose will be higher than from the first dose.

This increase in plasma concentration of the drug will occur continuously on repeated dosing (drug accumulation occurs) until a steady state at which drug elimination is equal to drug administration is reached. This is known as the plateau principle of drug accumulation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of breathing difficulty, facial swelling, and palpitations following a bee sting. He was immediately given an intramuscular injection of a drug in 1:1000 dilution. The drug acts on which of the following receptor to improve the patient's breathing difficulty?
questions.solution:
The patient's complaints of breathing difficulty, facial swelling, and palpitations following a bee sting are suggestive of anaphylactic shock. The drug of choice for anaphylaxis is intramuscular adrenaline (0.5ml in 1:1000 dilution). Activation of beta 2 receptors causes bronchodilation. Hence, adrenaline action on the beta 2 receptors improves the breathing difficulty in this patient. Apart from this, beta 2 receptors also inhibit the secretion from mast cells.

Other options:

Receptor Action Use in anaphylaxis treatment 
Alpha 1 and Alpha 2 Vasoconstriction Increase in BP
Beta 1 Cardiac stimulation Increase in BP
Beta 2 Bronchodilation Reverse bronchoconstriction 


The net effect of adrenaline on BP: Adrenaline rapidly increases blood pressure by reversing vasodilation and improving cardiac output. This is critical for preventing shock and ensuring adequate perfusion to vital organs during anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with diarrhea, sweating, excessive lacrimation, and salivation. His pulse rate is 55/min and his plasma cholinesterase level was 50U/mL. Which of the following can be used to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of organophosphate poisoning and IV atropine is the treatment of choice.

The organophosphates commonly used as pesticides are anticholinesterases. Toxicity occurs by excessive inhalation of vapors, ingestion, or percutaneous absorption. It inhibits the cholinesterase activity which results in an increase of acetylcholine, leading to cholinergic symptoms.

The predominant initial signs are of muscarinic excess which includes: (DUMBBELSS)

  • Diarrhea
  • Urination
  • Miosis
  • Bronchospasm
  • Bradycardia
  • Emesis
  • Lacrimation
  • Salivation
  • Sweating

This may be followed by cognitive disturbances, convulsions, and neuromuscular blockade.

Treatment:

  • Maintenance of vital signs particularly respiration
  • Removal of clothing and washing of the skin
  • IV atropine 2- 5 mg. If IV administration is not possible, then 2 mg IM every 5-10 minutes (till muscarinic symptoms disappear)
  • Pralidoxime, a cholinesterase reactivator can also be used for treatment

questions.text: A patient was given 200 mg of a drug that follows first-order kinetics. If 75 mg is excreted in 90 minutes, how much drug will remain at the end of 6 hours?
questions.solution:
30.5 mg of the drug will remain after 6 hours.

In first order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is excreted in a given time. 

75 mg of 200 mg is excreted in 90 minutes

75/200 = 37.5/100 = 0.375 is eliminated 

After 90 minutes; 200 mg-75 mg = 125 mg remains 

The next 90 minutes (after 180 minutes) = 125 x 0.375 = 46.875 mg is eliminated, and 125-46.875 = 78.125 mg remains 

The next 90 minutes (after 270 minutes) = 78.125 x 0.375 = 29.297 mg is eliminated, and 78.125-29.297 = 48.828 remains 

The next 90 minutes (after 360 minutes) = 48.828 x 0.375 = 18.310 mg is eliminated, 48.828-18.310 = 30.518 mg remains after 6 hours. 

A simpler way to calculate 

3/8 fraction is excreted in 90 minutes → 5/8 remains after 90 minutes.

6 hours (360 min) is 4 times of 90 minutes.

So 200 x (5/8)(5/8)(5/8)(5/8) = 30.518 mg remains after 360 minutes

questions.text: The dose-response curve is plotted for drug A both in the presence and absence of drug B.  What type of effect does drug B have on drug A?
questions.solution:
Drug B has a competitive antagonistic effect on drug A.

In competitive antagonism, DRC shows a parallel rightward shift. Competitive antagonism occurs when the agonist and antagonist compete for the same binding site on the receptor. The response curve for the agonist shifts to the right in a concentration-related manner by the antagonist.

In non-competitive antagonism, there is flattening of the agonist DRC. Non-competitive antagonism effects occur when the agonist and antagonist bind to different sites on the receptor. ( allosteric site) and inhibits the response. The response curve progressively shifts in a right and downward direction until it reaches a limiting value when the allosteric site is fully occupied.

In competitive agonism, the curve shifts to the left.

In partial agonism, the partial agonist which has an affinity for the same receptor, also competes with and antagonizes a full agonist, while producing a submaximal response.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old female patient diagnosed with migraine visited her doctor and noticed a new drug, rimegepant, on one of the migraine pamphlets. Which of the following information would have been correctly mentioned in the pamphlet?
  1. Orally administered
  2. CGRP receptor agonist
  3. Used for treatment of an acute attack of migraine
  4. Can be used for migraine prophylaxis
  5. Nausea is a major side effect
questions.solution:
Rimegepant is a recently approved orally-administered CGRP (calcitonin gene-related peptide) receptor antagonist used in the treatment of an acute attack of migraine with or without aura. It is not effective for migraine prophylaxis.

The major side effect associated with the drug is nausea. Because it is metabolized by CYP3A4, concomitant administration with CYP3A4 inducers/inhibitors is avoided. It is also avoided in Child-Pugh C cirrhosis as it is hepatically metabolized. 

CGRP receptor antagonists are:

  • Rimegepant
  • Ubrogepant
  • Erenumab

Rimegepant and ubrogepant are used only for the treatment of an acute attack of migraine while erenumab is only indicated for prophylaxis of migraine in adults.

 

CGRP Antagonists (Anti-CGRP ligand monoclonal antibody): Used for migraine prophylaxis

  1. Eptinezumab
  2. Galcanezumab -Also used for the treatment of episodic cluster headache
  3. Fremanezumab

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination with no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia
